name: Masked Lapwing (Northern Subspecies)
description: The masked lapwing is a sturdy bird with long legs. It is ash-gray above and white below, with a black crown and yellow beak. The male has larger yellow facial wattles than the female. At the zoo, we keep the northern subspecies V. m. miles, which has a white neck.
spread_note: Mainly the northern and eastern parts of the continent
image_alt: Masked lapwing, photo: Rošický, Prague Zoo
reproduction: Females typically lay 4 eggs in a ground nest.
attractions: Lapwings are usually shy, but during nesting season, they become very conspicuous. They nest in any open grassy area. The pair fiercely defends their nesting territory, attempting to drive away or distract predators from the nest. During attacks, they use a prominent spur on the wing bend. Fledged young often stay with their parents for the next year. They communicate with a wide range of sounds.
breeding: We have kept them at the zoo since 2010.
